q.a: this is very important, because this is usually where a large percentage of your ideas come from, so it is important to have a technique for this. Use a voice memo app (most phones have them) and be quick and professional about how you frame it. establish where the root of the key is, establish where the time is, and correctly count it off, so there is no confusion about where the key and time are oriented. any hints about the groove or tempo are also very helpful, (perhaps compare it to another song's tempo, if that helps) and any other hints about how the idea is oriented in the song ('this is the top of of the chorus' or 'this would the the end title line of a chorus' or 'this would be a verse line' or any other hints you can think of). and if there are any specific chord things, mention that too, like if you know the whole thing starts on the 4 chord, or something like that. but most importantly remember to orient the key (sing a quick do re mi reference or something) and properly count off the time, and sing the thing, preferably a couple of times. overall your total demo &plus description should be about 15 to 20 seconds

q.a: there is pressure from all sides. some people want the video to come out sooner. some people want me to work less, and 'take vacations.' some people want me to give opinions about the latest films and tv shows. some people want me to make more short videos. some people want me to make songs. some people want me to make more journal clips. some people want me to answer more questions. some people think i answer too many questions. some people want me to collaborate with their favorite artists. some people want me to make videos for their business. these are some of the many kinds of pressure i receive on a daily basis
q.q: I see a lot of questions asking when is the next "history of" video.  But the real question is, do you feel pressured to please the people who are constantly berating you, trying to find out when the video is coming out?

q.a: but the only kind of pressure i pay attention to is the pressure that was present before any of those, which is whoops i have no social life but my mind has been exploding for as long as i can remember, and it needs to be put on display ASAP in as many ways as possible until people understand
q.q: Or do you not care what others think, and care only to work at a pace that suits you?  Or perhaps a combination of both?

q.a: the song was actually recorded around early 2010. it was called "this song yeah" and it's hardly a song, it's just me slamming a major chord several times in a row. During 2014, as part of the weekly content schedule, one of the videos each week is supposed to be a 'music video' which is when you make a video to go along to a song that's already recorded. so for a thrill, i decided to try an instrumental song. i picked "this song yeah." the idea that worked best was a jar of peanut butter. when the video was done, it only made sense to change the title. most of the time i aim for strict musical accuracy in my videos, because it is usually more thrilling, especially for musician viewers, but in this particular video the notes are ignored. mainly because it is impossible to play a major triad with a peanut butter jar
q.q: I know the new vid is comin', so i will ask about something else. peanut butter song: you recorded the jar hits on to a MIDI track and then just moved the notes to form the major and then add 9 chords, right? It seems more practical than just playing chords in sync or trying to re-sync 'em. just that. keep it awesome and hellyeahish.

q.a: the 'graphics' phase was finished on feb 7. after that, the process is a little bit more confusing to explain. it's a lot of smaller things -- final narration, jingle vocals, editing jingles and narration, mixing, re-alignment to fit final narration timing, and the score. the score is the most subtantial item of all of those, but not as large as 'graphics.' it is hard to exactly explain the process because i have been bouncing around depending on whether it's day or night (vocal recording, etc) and also i was sick and had lingering sick voice for a couple weeks, so during that time i made an early detour into doing the score, somewhere around feb 19. so i basically locked up the narration timing up until 7:50 (that was as far as i had gotten) and started on the score. by the time i reached 7:50 in the score (this was around march 2 i guess), i was able to resume vocals, and was bouncing around between doing jingles and narration.  narration is now solidly in place with correct timing, video re-alignment to fit that new timing is done, now starting on the rest of the score, from 8min to the end. once the score is done, it is just the small little tasks like year labels, other labels, graphics adjustments, mixing, etc etc etc but these small tasks tend to fly by very fast, and once the score is done it tends to be a slippery slope to the end of the process. this is what i know from experience on doing the previous long video of this type. i hope that makes sense

q.q: yesterday I was in the Dollar Tree with my grandma and we were checking out and the cashier looks at me and I'm thinking "what the fuck that guy looks like bill" and I look at his name tag whilst he's is engaged in conversation with my grandma and it says "RYEN" and I'm like thinking... "fuck, this dude is either not bill Wurtz or he's bill Wurtz under cover." And then he looks at me. And I stare at him. And he says "I like your shirt, man. I've listened to Abbey Road so many times. Rock on" and I just keep staring at him and I look to my grandma and to him and I'm sure I looked like I was going insane and then he starts talking again and he's like "I even love that stupid octopuses garden song" and I'm like "bill?" And he's like "what" and my grandma is like "no it was the other guy in the Beatles who wrote that song" and then he gets in an argument with my grandma about who wrote that song and I'm just standing there watching him scan my grandmas adult diapers and scream at her and in my head I'm thinking "THIS IS BILL FUCKING WURTZ or possibly his twin brother that lives in Florida AND HE KNOWS ALL THE SECRETS TO THE UNIVERSE" because he was winning the argument and I assumed he knew everything else as well. and basically: this shook me, bill.

q.a: like i started trying to write songs in 2007, then i tried some different approaches, then i really started writing a lot more in 2009, then i tried some more approaches, then in 2010 i recorded maybe 5% of the songs i had written, and then kept writing more anyway, and wrote way way more, then in 2011 i decided that the stuff i was writing was cool but way too insane and i should try to do more normal stuff. so in 2011 i wrote a bunch of normal stuff, and recorded maybe 25% of those, then i got bored with normal stuff and wrote more crazy stuff. and finally in 2012 i was like 'what the fuck is going on here i've written so much stuff and i'll never have time to record it all because it takes longer to record than to write and i keep wanting to write more.' so i organized everything i had ever written, and then wrote more. so throughout 2012-13 i wrote like crazy, updating and organizing everything i had written, fixing it, updating it, etc. and in 2013 i was like, ok, wowwww, now i really think i'm a pro writer and i've got so many hundreds of songs written. time to record it and maybe put it online. then i built a webiste. then i filled the website with all the previous recordings, etc. but then i was like, wait hold on, what about videos? i've wanted to do videos for a long time and i bet it would work, and it would be a good way to get people to pay attention to me. so i started making videos on a regular basis for a couple years and also making stupid tweets to attract attention. then the attention came. guess what now it's time to do the songs i mentioned before

to the person who asked about death being necessary: death by ageing is caused by deterioration of the telomeres that cap chromosomes, which means that eventually the cells aren't able to divide anymore, so they die. it's called cell senescence (and some cells like rat brain cells don't have this problem and they can keep on dividing forever). so it is possible that in the future we could maybe prevent death, by altering DNA so that the telomeres don't go bad. (telomeres shorten after each cell replication). I don't know if you'll post this but I think it's cool info that people don't hear about unless they search for it specifically

q.a: i will explain a single page first (the multi-page spread is another issue)... let's say there is just one page of notation, like 8 bars or whatever.... I make the notation in a notation program, and screenshot it. (then i actually make several alignment adjustments in graphics, because notation programs are incredibly finicky, it's easier to adjust things in graphics)... then i save it how i want. then i use graphics to erase the last note (and any chord that goes along with it.) i erase notes on a staff by just dragging empty staff over it. and i "save as" and then add a 1 to the file name. repeat, keep erasing the next note and 'save as'. then you have a stack of files all in order. then import. then allign the timing. it's the exact same way i do text, but with text i type it out and screenshot each frame, and delete words (easier, instead of erasing them). the delete technique would not work in a notation program, because the notes and alignment will change as you delete them. that's why i use graphics. it's not that hard, and i'm not even using a graphics program. just an image preview program, and i'm just copying and pasting boxes. the mccartney video was a bit more ambitious because i wanted to do a steady scroll. so i thought it would be good to make one huge image file that is the entire length of the score. and then do the erase per frame technique.... so then all the frames were huge... and then export that to a really high res video and scroll the video??? i don't remember if this was successful, but you run into major problems when you try to do huge things like that. processing power limitations, etc. Same sort of crisis occured when i was trying to do the zoom out on the japanese army. i ended up having to somehow break the task into smaller pieces. if i recall. i somehow succeeded in getting a steady scroll on the notation, only to find out that it was too hard to read when it's moving like that!! so i ended up keeping it still and then sliding forward page by page. if i had known the steady scroll wasn't going to work, i probably would have broken it into pages from the start

q.a: i'm not sure you are understanding quite how perfect pitch works. the name of perfect pitch is misleading. it makes more sense to call it 'absolute pitch.' and you don't need to have absolute pitch to know whether something is out of tune with itself. only to know whether it is overall tuned to A=440hz. and whether or not something is tuned to A=440hz does not affect whether or not it sounds 'in tune'. anyone claiming to be annoyed by something because it is not tuned to A=440 is lying, and using it as an excuse to brag that they have absolute pitch. in fact some people even claim things are not A=440 when they actually are, especially nowadays, with most music being made on computers where all the instruments are by default set to A=440
q.q: If you had to choose between having absolutely perfect pitch but always getting annoyed when someone is out of tune at all, or always being out of tune but being able to enjoy music as you do now, what would you choose?
